author: Deleted User
content: <@!301186049323958275> Why didnt ethereum made a a system that can check that all parameters required are achieved before starting to make the transaction

author: sky.cactus
content: The state of the world may change between when the transaction is initially checked and when the transaction is eventually included.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, if you are trading on a DEX, the price may change over time causing a transaction to become invalid, or become valid, or alternate back and forth.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can't know for sure what the world state the transaction executes against will be until you actually execute it at its final position in the blockchain.

author: sky.cactus
content: The system *does* do a bunch of validity checks on the transaction before passing it around via gossip, it doesn't just blindly accept everything.  However, EVM execution specifically is delayed until final inclusion time, at which point the transaction has already cost the network in terms of gossip, storage, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum has global data storage, and people can write logic that is conditional on that storage.

author: sky.cactus
content: Bitcoin's only storage is UTXOs, which have very limited logic that can be applied to them and a transaction has limited visibility into UTXOs besides the ones it is spending from.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, Bitcoin script can't do much besides transferring BTC, so it is *far* easier to make guarantees about transaction validity than on Ethereum.
